awd_titl_txt: Dynamic Barriers to Swimming Agents in Complex Fluid Flows
awd_abstract_narration:
The motion, orientation, and control of self-propelled bodies in aqueous environments is an active field of scientific research.  This field clearly has important engineering applications to, for example, swarms of autonomous underwater vehicles, collections of aerial drones, or swimming microrobots.  This field is also important for understanding the fundamental physics of swimming organisms, such as bacteria, larvae, or even artificial colloidal particles.  Many past studies focused on the interactions between bodies (agents) within a stationary ambient fluid; these interactions can lead to collective behavior like schooling, flocking, and group alignment. However, few studies have explored the motion of swimming agents in complicated flows that are caused by external disturbances.  The current research will explore how isolated, self-propelled swimming agents are transported within such a flow.  This is important for understanding swimming in the "real world", where swimmers often encounter nonnegligible, even turbulent, background flows.  This work seeks to identify regions that are inaccessible to a swimmer, or accessible only after a long time.  In many cases, these regions are delineated by geometric barriers that are not imposed by physical walls, but rather arise from subtle interactions between the dynamics of the swimmer and that of the flow.  This work will develop techniques to predict where such barriers exist.  These studies will be conducted in collaboration with a Bucknell University investigator, who is conducting experiments on bacteria in microfluidic flows.

For several decades it has been understood that invariant manifolds are the critical structures controlling the transport of passive tracers in fluids exhibiting chaotic advection.  More recently, Lagrangian coherent structures have provided an analogous framework for passive advection in unsteady, aperiodic flows. The objective of this research is to extend these theories to agents that are both advected in the fluid and propelled under their own power. The passive invariant manifolds, and Lagrangian coherent structures, are no longer the most relevant objects. Rather, new objects called swimming invariant manifolds (SwIMs), which depend explicitly on the swimming speed, appear to be the key structures. This research will develop the theoretical framework for SwIMs, assess their importance to the transport of swimmers, and apply this framework to various scenarios, including: (i) swimmers of differing aspect ratios; (ii) steady, periodic, and aperiodic fluid flows; (iii) flows in 2D and 3D; (iv) hyperbolic versus elliptic flows; (v) the influence of stochastic effects in the swimmer's direction, and (vi) interactions between swimmers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the study of swimmers, either microorganisms or engineered microswimmers, in applied fluid flows from the perspective of dynamical systems theory.  We provided both experimental evidence (with our experimental collaborator Tom Solomon at Bucknell) and a theoretical framework for understanding dynamical barriers to swimmer movement. The key theoretical construct was a 2D dynamical barrier living in the 3D position-orientation "phase space" of the system and the fold of this barrier, which projects to a 1D curve in the original 2D position space of the swimmer. We also developed a thorough bifurcation analysis for swimming stagnation (fixed) points and swimmer periodic motion in a vortex flow. This analysis allows one to understand the stability of swimmer dynamics and the trapping of swimmers within vortices. We also studied how noise can induce aggregation of swimmers as well as a novel “semi-classical” treatment of noise. Broader impacts: During the course of this work, the PI organized a biweekly interdisciplinary reading group on active materials at UC Merced, which has become an established center of soft matter and biophysics. The PI also co-organized a Telluride conference in Summer 2021 on “Active Matter”, which included swimmer dynamics.  The grant supported one postdoc (Simon Berman). Dr. Berman spent part of his time at Bucknell University, working with undergraduate students, and served as the principal advisor for two undergraduate theory students. Dr. Berman and his students presented their work at several conferences, including the APS Division of Fluid Dynamics meeting and Dynamics Days.  A more detailed discussion of results follows.

For a self-propelled swimmer within a complex, possibly time-dependent, 2D fluid flow, we studied which regions of the fluid the swimmer can access. We asked: (1) Do local or global dynamical barriers prevent the swimmer from moving between points in the fluid? (2) Does the dynamical systems analysis of pattern formation for front-propagation systems provide similarly deep insights for the patterns of swimmers? Our work answered both questions in the affirmative. Certainly, the dynamics admit swimming fixed points, where the swimmer stays still. From these, we can compute "invariant manifolds", called swimming invariant manifolds (SwIMs). These are mathematically analogous to structures (called BIMs) for reaction fronts propagating through fluids, but SwIMs have their own unique properties and peculiarities. A central goal of our research was to understand how SwIMs are similar to BIMs, how they are different, and how these properties depend on the shape of the swimmer. 

In collaboration with the Solomon group, we developed the foundation for an invariant manifold (SwIM) framework that describes barriers for swimmers in laminar flows. The experiments used a genetically-mutated smooth-swimming strain of Bacillus subtilis bacteria, which tend to swim in straight lines with constant speed, as well as wild-type bacteria, which randomly change direction via a tumbling mechanism. Both strains formed active tracers in a laminar, hyperbolic flow generated in a microfluidic cross-channel. We demonstrated that SwIMs act as absolute two-way barriers to smooth swimmers in the 3D position-orientation space. The folds of the SwIMs, called SwIM edges, project to one-way barriers in position space.  The existence—and importance—of SwIM edges is one of the key findings from this NSF-funded research.  We also showed that SwIM edges are important in vortex flows.

We found several trapping mechanisms for swimmers in a vortex lattice, depending on the swimmer's speed and shape.  In particular, swimmers may be trapped within so-called "invariant tori" in the 3D position-orientation phase space.  These tori surround stable periodic orbits, which drive trapping for low-to-intermediate swimming speed. We constructed a bifurcation diagram for this periodic orbit and found that the values where it becomes unstable or disappears predict where trapping ceases in numerical simulations.  Our calculations also revealed parameter regimes where trapping was enhanced due to attracting "limit cycles".  This work also revealed a surprising regime where high-speed, perpendicular swimmers could be trapped due to stable fixed points. 

In another study, we investigated swimmers in a laminar Kolmogorov (i.e. spatially sinusoidal) flow. Through an analysis without noise, we found that swimmers favor either cross-stream or rotational drift, depending on their swimming speed and shape. When including rotational noise, we found that swimmers are driven into certain parts of phase space, leading to a nonuniform steady-state distribution. This distribution transitions from aggregation in low-shear regions to aggregation in high-shear regions as the swimmer’s speed, shape, and rotational diffusivity are varied.

Finally, we investigated random fluctuations of swimmer angle near one-way barriers, BIMs, in the 2D hyperbolic flow. Such noise significantly increases the chance that a swimmer crosses a BIM, which then blocks it from returning to its initial position. We used a “semiclassical” method to compute the probability of escaping either left or right. This mirrors the semiclassical approximation in quantum mechanics.  The semiclassical results nicely agreed with direct ensemble simulations.
